awd_titl_txt: Multi-Material Properties via Multi-Field Processing on a Single Constituent Set
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research that will contribute new knowledge enabling the processing of polymer matrix composites with controlled heterogenous architectures that possess spatially varying mechanical and electronic/magnetic properties throughout the structure. The work extends the range of materials and structures accessible via additive processing techniques promoting the progress of science and advancing national prosperity. Almost all modern materials consist of a mixture or composite of materials which can act synergistically to produce interesting and useful properties which do not exist in any of the constituents. The research looks to the simplification of these additive processing techniques by applying external electrical and magnetic fields during the manufacturing process that leads to a spontaneous internal ordering of the two phases. While state-of-the-art multi-material additive manufacturing utilizes complex machinery and separate reservoirs for each material, this process would simplify manufacturing by fabricating parts with a range of material properties from a single material reservoir. Such processing has the capacity to revolutionize additive manufacturing by fabricating fully functioning devices through the control of the micro-architecture of the composites and hence their material properties. The work will seek out material and processing condition pairings that can achieve dichotomous properties, allowing the source material to produce materials that are stiff or compliant, magnetic or non-magnetic, conducting or insulating, etc. as needed locally during component fabrication. For example, instead of needing conducting metals surrounded by insulating polymer to fabricate parts with integrated wiring, this work will determine specific processing techniques to produce locally conductive and insulating regions within the part from the single material reservoir. Structured polymer matrix composites which are critical to a wide range of industries including aerospace, automotive, and healthcare developed through additive manufacturing would simply product development and open new application areas benefiting the U.S. economy and society. The outreach and educational components of the work will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education in an emerging field.
 
 
The goal of this research is to experimentally and theoretically study and quantify the ability of uniform and non-uniform electromagnetic fields and their gradients to develop micro-architectures in polymer matrix composites that have not been achieved using traditional uniform and single field processing.  An electromagnetically assisted manufacturing process can provide a viable, lower-cost route to multi-material properties by reducing the complexity of these manufacturing systems down to a set of process variables that lead to desired properties. Externally applied electric and magnetic fields act orthogonally on the embedded barium hexaferrite particles within the uncured composite due to the particles' planar shape and crystallographic c-axis magnetization, allowing multi-axis control of particle alignments.  Furthermore, externally induced dielectrophoretic and magnetophoretic particle-particle interactions allow control of the arrangement of aggregates of particles, providing a second hierarchical level of control.  While dielectrophoresis and magnetophoresis are well known phenomena, this research will provide new knowledge of how regulated interactions of both fields with anisotropic particles can be used to develop micro-architectures that produce extremum dielectric, magnetic, and mechanical properties. The research team will perform computational multi-physics simulations of the electromagnetic field processing to predict resulting micro-architectures.  Finite element modeling of the resulting micro-architectures will then provide estimates of resulting material properties.  Experimental fabrication of these composites using predicted process variables, combined with an array of electromagnetic and mechanical characterization, will be used to refine simulations and to direct iterative experimental and computational trials, closing the loop with a multi-level Monto-Carlo optimization scheme. Results of this work will provide data on the process parameter, constituent, effective property design space that others may use to fabricate materials with tailored properties in a general electromagnetic processing context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This work developed experimental, theoretical and computational materials processing frameworks to assist development of universal 3D printing platforms capable of producing parts with multi-material properties from a single feedstock. By applying electromagnetic fields to polymer matrix composite slurries, controllable microarchitectures were formed thereby controlling material properties. Machine learning algorithms coupled with simulations of electromagnetic field processing allowed users to select a target set of properties, then have the framework determine the required processing fields. 

Intellectual Merit

The work was divided into experimental and modeling tasks for the main grant, and data science and intern related tasks for the supplements. From the experimental side, new methods of functionally coating particles for dispersion and systems for generating orthogonal electric and magnetic fields enabling multifield processing were developed.  Characterization of these multifield-processed PMCs showed hierarchical ordering of the barium hexaferrite filler into macro-chains, micro-chains, and particle stacks.  Results showed that magnetic field processing promoted short-range order (stacks) while electric field processing promoted long-range order (macro-chains). Moreover, short range ordering affected magnetic properties while long range order drove dielectric properties. Multifield processing techniques were further shown capable of producing controlled anisotropy and controlling relative magnitudes of properties by varying the strength and orientation of coupled electric and magnetic fields. The ratio of torques generated by the electric field and those created by the magnetic field were shown to be an important parameter in controlling hierarchical ordering, e.g. particle or stack ordering within micro- and macro-chains.

On the modeling and simulation, the work created a computational and theoretical framework for predicting material properties; and optimizing constituents and processing conditions to achieve target property sets.  This was achieved by coupling multiphysics particle dynamics simulations of the electromagnetic processing event with machine-learning-augmented computational homogenization of effective properties. Our work theoretically derived the important ratio of magnetic to dielectric torques. A new method of computing resistivity from pathfinding algorithms was also developed. Results of elastic, magnetic, and dielectric property estimation agreed well with experimental results and trends agreed well with effective medium theories. Simulations also recreated hierarchical ordering seen experimentally, particle ordering within chains, which traditional effective medium theories cannot capture.  Gaussian Process and Support Vector Regression machine learning algorithms used in optimization reduced the computational cost by an order of magnitude over gradient-based methods.

The work of the data science supplement focused on exploring the efficacy of training Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) and Support Vector Regression (SVR) algorithms to replace the particle dynamics simulation and computational homogenization frameworks that were used as the objectives of the larger constituents-processing optimization scheme. Results showed that GPR was more negatively influenced by low quality data, e.g. sparse data and/or data with large variance, than SVR.  Results lead to the conclusion that SVR is better suited to low quality data in cases such as this work where large computational costs lead to sparse and varied datasets, especially when low levels of nonlinearity are expected.

The work of the intern supplement focused on analyzing and optimizing magnetically driven blood separation devices used in cancer therapies. Optimization took the form of coupled magnetodynamics  and fluid mechanics multiphysics analysis of magnetic particles in a simulated blood plasma medium with the objective of increasing the forces acting on particles representing white blood cells.  Simulation results on an existing device showed that the accumulated net forces affecting on the particles in a fixed, static volume could be increased by changing the field profile of the magnetic flux lines seen by the flowing particles, e.g. by changing the underlying arrangement of the permanent magnets used in their system. Similarly, optimization of flowing particles over magnetic domains showed that the efficacy of the separation could be increased by modifying the magnet geometries. However, in some instances the magnet geometries might require emerging advances in the 3D printing of rare earth magnets.

 

Broader Impacts

The main grant developed a possible foundation for a novel universal 3D printer capable of printing multifunctional parts from single feedstocks with the possibility of greatly impacting the additive manufacturing industry. This intern work assisted the development of a biomedical device aimed at bringing an effective cancer therapy to a wider audience, possibly affecting millions suffering from cancer.  The grant also supported and engaged faculty; undergraduate, and graduate MS and PhD students; and underrepresented groups including women.  Results of these works, models developed, and techniques employed were used in an array of Penn State courses, were presented to international audiences at several conferences, and published in scientific and engineering journals.  Dissemination efforts brought knowledge and understanding of, and pathway toward, a new paradigm of “free functional complexity” in additive manufacturing to researchers. This new paradigm ultimately seeks to develop print platforms where producing parts with specified local properties and functionalities is no more complex than printing of a single monolithic material.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2023
Modified by: Paris R Von Lockette

Overview
